Expectation1: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation1: The build is stalled because no one can proceed until their core module is complete
Expectation2: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation2: The community study circle convenes tonight to discuss verses the person has not yet read.
Story:
I stare at the lines of code on my screen, the cursor blinking impatiently. The project manager’s message echoes in my mind: “We can’t move forward until your module is done.” My teammates are waiting, their progress stalled because of me. I know the pressure is on—I’m the engineer responsible for this core piece, and the deadline is tomorrow. 

But tonight is also the community Quran study circle. I promised myself I’d attend, to recite and reflect on the verses with everyone. I haven’t even read the assigned surahs yet. The thought of showing up unprepared, letting down my friends and my own spiritual goals, gnaws at me. 

My laptop glows in the dim light, and I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in. My mind races with technical solutions and Quranic verses, but I can’t seem to focus on either. I want to be the reliable engineer my team needs, and the committed Muslim my faith calls me to be. The clock ticks on, and I sit frozen, torn between two parts of myself, unsure which expectation I’ll have to let down.
